metadata.title: Title: Laboratory validation of an RNA/DNA hybrid tagmentation based mNGS 1 workflow on SARS-CoV-2 and other respiratory RNA viruses detection 2 3

abstract.text: 22 Background: Acute respiratory infection (ARI) caused by RNA viruses is still one of the 23 main diseases all over the world such as SARS-CoV-2 and Influenza A virus. mNGS was 24 a powerful tool for ethological diagnosis. But there were some challenges during mNGS 25 implementation in clinical settings such as time-consuming manipulation and lack of 26 comprehensive analytical validation.

27 Methods: We set up CATCH that was a mNGS method based on RNA and DNA hybrid 28 tagmentation via Tn5 transposon. Seven respiratory RNA viruses and three subtypes of 29 Influenza A virus had been used to test CATCH's capabilities of detection and semi-30 quantification. Analytical performance of SARS-CoV-2 and Influenza A virus had been 31 determined with reference standards. We compared accuracy of CATCH with quantitative

32 real time PCR by using clinical 98 samples from 64 COVID-19 patients. 33 Results: We minimized the library preparation process to 3 hours and handling time to 35 34 minutes. Duplicate filtered RPM of 7 respiratory viruses and 3 Influenza A virus subtypes 35

body_text.text: Respiratory tract infection, as a global burden on public health, has caused extensive 49 morbidity and mortality worldwide in the past decades. It is 3rd leading causes of death 50 among all ages by 2015 1 . In most cases of severe acute respiratory tract infections, RNA 51 viruses are pathogenic agents 2-4 . For example, the novel coronavirus SARS-CoV-2, 52 which is pathogen of COVID-19, has caused over 3 million people infected and 53 thousands death from December 2019 until now 5,6 . Traditional nucleotide analysis 54 methods for RNA viruses, such as quantitative reverse transcription PCR (qRT-PCR), are 55 . Hence, laboratory validation 71 including low limit of detection (LOD), precision, stability, effects of interference and 72 accuracy for RNA viruses in one single assay is essential for implementation of mNGS 73 for routine pathogen detection in clinical diagnostic laboratories.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted . . https://doi.org/10.1101 /2020 As of today, acute respiratory infection (ARI) caused by RNA viruses is still one of the 299 main diseases all over the world. According to the study of GLIMP 26 , EPIC 4 and CAP-300 China 27 , viral CAP diagnosis was 37.2% in Asia, 23% in the United States and 39.2% in 301 China. To improve our capabilities of etiological diagnosis in infectious disease, mNGS 302 assay has been applied and studied by many researchers and is gradually developed to be 303 a powerful tool in the past few years 28 . However, there were some challenges had to be 304 overcome during mNGS implementation in clinical settings such as laborious wet-lab 305 manipulations and lack of analytical validation following with a standard guideline 7,28 . In 306 this study, we set up a rapid, ease-to-use and sensitive clinical mNGS workflow--CATCH 307 based on RNA/DNA hybrids tagmentation via Tn5 for respiratory RNA viruses detection.

body_text.text: Besides, we provide a series data of its analytical performance of SARS-CoV-2 and 309 Influenza A virus. To our knowledge, this is the first study that testing comprehensive 310 performance of mNGS method based on RNA/DNA hybrids tagmentation for pathogen 311 detection. We highly consider that this newfound characteristic feature of Tn5 will help 312 mNGS implementation in clinical settings. Thus, solid data of accuracy and robustness of 313 CATCH in pathogen detection are required and important for its clinical uses.

Of many mNGS workflow for pathogen detection, capability for quantification is still a 315 challenge for many reasons 29-31 . Although CATCH cannot provide a well-defined 316 linearity of quantification for RNA viral detection, we still found that viral signals 317 . FIGREF13.text: 340 detective efficiency of CATCH. Moreover, as we knew, CATCH or other RNA/DNA 341 hybrid tagmentation method without optimization will have obvious 3'bias 13 . This feature 342 might also decrease possibility to capture viral fragments in clinical samples. For further 343 implementation, CATCH needs optimization for overcome this limitation. Last, we found 344 that CATCH can detect enrichment of opportunistic pathogen in oropharyngeal swabs of 345 COVID-19 patients comparing with healthy control. It indicated that we can expand 346 application of CATCH in fungal or bacterial detection in the near future. We also found 347 an interesting phenomenon that microbiome in oropharyngeal swabs among critical, 348 moderate patients and healthy people can be grouped in three clusters. Although we 349 excluded batch effects to some extent such as collection date and library preparation 350 batch, we still need more clinical data to confirm that there were significant difference in 351 microbiome of oropharyngeal swabs between COVID-19 patients and healthy people for 352 the reason that microbial profile might be affect by many artificial factors 33 . But it 353 inferred that CATCH have a strong potential on finding microbial biomarker for disease 354 evaluation and estimation 34-36 .
